greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = A099563(A001813(n)); the most significant digit in factorial base representation of (2n)! / n!.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10080
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
example: The terms A001813(0) .. A001813(8) in factorial base representation (A007623) look as:
Taking the first digit (actually: a place holder value) of each gives the terms a(0) .. a(8) of this sequence: 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 6, 1, 4, 1, ...
mathematica: factBaseIntDs[n_] := Module[{m, i, len, dList, currDigit}, i = 1; While[n > i!, i++ ]; m = n; len = i; dList = Table[0, {len}]; Do[ currDigit = 0; While[m >= j!, m = m - j!; currDigit++ ]; dList[[len - j + 1]] = currDigit, {j, i, 1, -1}]; If[dList[[1]] == 0, dList = Drop[dList, 1]]; dList]; (* taken from A007623,  Alonso del Arte, May 03 2006 *) f[n_] := factBaseIntDs[(2 n)!/n!][[1]]; Array[f, 96, 0] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Dec 25 2015 *)
program: A099563(n) = { my(i=2,dig=0); until(0==n, dig = n % i; n = (n - dig)/i; i++); return(dig); };
(define (A265894 n) (A265890bi (+ 1 n) n)) ;; Code for A265890bi given in A265890.
xref: Cf. A265898 (positions of ones), A265899 (of descents), A266120 (local maxima just before those descents).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 24 2015
